div1.head: Letter from Albert G. Love to Jefferson Randolph Kean, January 5, 1942
div1.opener:
AGL:jm
IN REPLY REFER TO S.G.O.
WAR DEPARTMENT
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL
WASHINGTON
January 5, 1942
General Jefferson R. Kean,
2804 N Street N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Kean:
div1.p:
I hope you will pardon me this typewritten
letter but it has one advantage, namely that it will be easier
to read than my rather illegible handwriting.

We appreciated so very much the fine Christmas
greeting from you and Mrs. Kean.

I am so happy to have the article by Dr. P. S.
Hench with the photograph of the painting by Mr. Dean Cornwell.
I am planning to have the photograph with the reproduction of the
key framed so that it may be preserved during my lifetime and I
hope later by my children.

I am particularly happy that your picture was
included in the group as was certainly most appropriate. You look
somewhat fierce and quite military. I can see, however, in it
the kindly features of my old chief who has done so much for me
and for all of the Medical Department of the Army.
div1.closer:
Cordially, Albert G. Love Albert G. Love,
Colonel, U. S. Army,
Retired.
ALL COMMUNICATIONS SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO “THE SURGEON GENERAL, U. S. ARMY, WASHINGTON, D.C.”
